text: Law of the Passover. The LORD said to Moses and Aaron: This is the Passover statute. No foreigner may eat of it.

Great sacrifices were offered on that day, and they rejoiced, for God had given them cause for great rejoicing. The women and the children joined in, and the rejoicing at Jerusalem could be heard from far off.
Instead, he received him with honor, introduced him to all his friends, and gave him presents. He also ordered his friends and soldiers to obey him as they would himself.

He then took up a collection among all his soldiers, amounting to two thousand silver drachmas, which he sent to Jerusalem to provide for an expiatory sacrifice. In doing this he acted in a very excellent and noble way, inasmuch as he had the resurrection in mind;
“When an unclean spirit goes out of a person it roams through arid regions searching for rest but finds none.
Calling his disciples to himself, he said to them, “Amen, I say to you, this poor widow put in more than all the other contributors to the treasury.
Blessed is that servant whom his master on arrival finds doing so.
For they preferred human praise to the glory of God.
